questions.text: A patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus experiences hypoglycemia and sustains a fall. Due to incoherent speech, a CT scan is performed and reveals a substantial subdural hematoma (SDH) with a volume greater than 30 cc. What should be the immediate next step in management?

choices.text: Stabilize the patient and urgently seek a neurosurgical consultation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Perform a Craniotomy

Explanation:

  • The scenario presents a case of acute subdural hematoma with significant volume (>30 cc) requiring immediate surgical intervention. In acute SDH, CT imaging shows hyperdense (white) appearance, and when the volume exceeds 30 cc, there is a substantial risk of brain compression and herniation.
  • Emergency Craniotomy represents the definitive treatment in this setting, allowing for immediate evacuation of the hematoma to prevent further neurological deterioration and potential fatal complications.

 

Acute SDH vs Chronic SDH:

Feature

Acute SDH

Chronic SDH

Timing

0-72 hours

>3 weeks

Clinical Features
  • Rapid deterioration
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Focal deficits
  • High mortality
  • Gradual onset
  • Confusion
  • Headache
  • Gait disturbance
  • Better prognosis

Risk Factors
  • Severe trauma
  • Young adults
  • Coagulopathy
  • Elderly
  • Brain atrophy
  • Anticoagulation
  • Minor trauma

CT Findings
  • Hyperdense crescent
  • Immediate mass effect
  • Hypodense/mixed density
  • Bilateral in 20-30%
  • Gradual mass effect

Management
  • Emergency craniotomy
  • Reverse coagulopathy
  • ICU care
  • Burr hole drainage
  • Hold anticoagulation
  • May observe small ones

 

Administer Mannitol (Option A) is used to manage elevated intracranial pressure, but it is not the definitive treatment for a large subdural hematoma. While mannitol can temporarily reduce intracranial pressure, it does not address the underlying compression from the hematoma, which requires surgical evacuation.

Administer Aspirin and Clopidogrel (Option B) would be contraindicated in acute SDH as these antiplatelet agents could worsen the bleeding. In fact, if the patient was previously on these medications, they would need to be discontinued and potentially reversed depending on the clinical situation.

Stabilize the patient and urgently seek a neurosurgical consultation (Option D) while important, delays the definitive treatment needed in this case. Given the large volume of the hematoma and altered mental status, immediate surgical intervention through craniotomy is required rather than waiting for further consultation.

questions.text: Young male has sustained Femur shaft fracture after RTA and internal fixation was done. 2 days later he develops shortness of breath with confusion and petechial rash. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) FES

Explanation: This patient has the classic triad of Fat Embolism Syndrome following a long bone fracture and orthopedic surgery:

  • Respiratory distress (shortness of breath)
  • Neurological symptoms (confusion, altered sensorium)
  • Petechial rash (typically on upper chest, axillae, and conjunctiva)

Fat emboli enter the circulation from bone marrow after trauma or fixation and lodge in pulmonary and systemic microvasculature, producing respiratory compromise, brain dysfunction, and a petechial rash due to dermal capillary occlusion.

ARDS (Option B): Can occur after trauma but doesn’t present with the petechial rash; onset is usually a bit later and is related to widespread inflammatory lung injury.

Pulmonary embolism (Option C): Causes acute dyspnea and hypoxia but usually lacks neurologic signs and rash; most often from DVT.

Pleural effusion (Option D): Would present with unilateral decreased breath sounds, not acute neuro changes or rash.

questions.text: Which is the best confirmatory method to ensure the central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chest x-ray:

Explanation:

Importance of Chest X-ray in Central Line Placement

  • Initial Assessment:
    • A chest X-ray should be performed immediately after internal jugular and subclavian line placement to confirm correct catheter placement and rule out iatrogenic pneumothorax.
       
  • Post-Procedure Verification:
    • It is crucial to verify catheter placement and ensure no complications, like pneumothorax, following the procedure.
       
  • Ipsilateral Side Approach:
    • If the internal jugular central venous line (CVL) insertion fails, move to the ipsilateral subclavian vein.
    • A chest X-ray or ultrasound should be performed before attempting the opposite side to prevent bilateral pneumothoraces.

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: An RTA patient has received 4 packed RBC within a few hours. Which of the following will be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Hypocalcemia:

Explanation:

  • Stored packed RBCs contain citrate as an anticoagulant. Rapid transfusion leads to citrate binding ionized calcium in the recipient’s blood, causing acute hypocalcemia.
  • Citrate toxicity is more likely when large volumes of blood are transfused rapidly, as in massive transfusion protocols. The liver normally metabolizes citrate, but in shock or hypothermia this clearance is impaired.
  • Clinical signs: Perioral numbness, paresthesia, muscle cramps, tetany, hypotension, and prolonged QT interval on ECG.

Massive Blood Transfusion:

  • Definition: Replacement of blood volume exceeding patient’s total blood volume within 24 hrs (or >10 units of PRBC).
  • Acute complications:
    • Metabolic: Hypocalcemia (citrate toxicity), hypomagnesemia, hyperkalemia (from hemolysis), hypothermia, metabolic alkalosis.
    • Coagulopathy: Due to dilution of platelets and clotting factors.
    • Volume overload & ARDS.
  • Prevention: Warm blood before transfusion, monitor electrolytes, give calcium gluconate if needed, replace platelets & FFP in balanced ratios.

Key electrolyte changes in massive transfusion:

Electrolyte

Cause

Change

Calcium

Citrate binding

↓ (Hypocalcemia)

Potassium

Leakage from stored RBCs

↑ (Hyperkalemia)

Magnesium

Citrate binding

↓ (Hypomagnesemia)

Sodium

Usually normal; slight ↑ if using older preservatives

—

Incorrect Options:

Hypernatremia (Option A) – Not a major finding; sodium content in stored blood is minimal.

Hyponatremia (Option B) – Not typically caused by transfusion.

Hyperkalemia (Option D) – Possible in prolonged storage, but acute citrate-induced hypocalcemia is more characteristic in rapid large transfusions.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Defibrillation

Explanation:

  • The given ECG shows ventricular fibrillation and the next step of management is defibrillation since this is a shockable rhythm.

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Ventricular Fibrillation

Asystole

Ventricular Tachycardia

Pulseless Electrical Activity

 

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation (Option A)

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (Option C) (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Immediate Recognition

Identify Non-Shockable Rhythm: Recognize asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA).

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓
Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓
Establish intravenous or intraosseous lines for medication administration.

↓
Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Administer IV/IO after the first 2 minutes of CPR.

↓

Identify Rhythm

  • Non-Shockable Rhythm: Continue CPR and administer epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.

Goal: To increase the likelihood of developing a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is necessary for effective defibrillation.

  • Shockable Rhythm: Administer a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

↓
Advanced Airway Management

Airway: Secure the airway with endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation for adequate oxygenation.

↓
Continue CPR

Resume chest compressions for 2 minutes.

↓
Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Primary Focus: Address reversible causes, especially hypothermia.

↓
Repeat CPR and Epinephrine

Cycle: Continue repeating CPR and epinephrine administration every 3-5 minutes.

 

Synchronized cardioversion (Option B) is used to reset the abnormal heart rhythm and is given in synchronisation with the R wave in the ECG (delivered at the peak of the R wave). It is performed in arrhythmias where the heart is still contracting but irregularly, such as Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT), Atrial Fibrillation (AF), and Atrial Flutter.

0.5 mg atropine (Option D) is indicated for symptomatic bradycardia and bot in a pulseless patient.

questions.text: All of the following is used in the management of breathless patients at a high altitude of 3000 mts except.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intravenous digoxin

Explanation: A breathless patient at a high altitude of 3000 meters suggests High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE), and intravenous digoxin is not used in its management.

 

High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE):

  • Risk Factors:
    • Rapid ascent, history of HAPE, respiratory infections, cold temperatures.
    • Cardiopulmonary abnormalities (e.g., mitral stenosis, primary pulmonary hypertension) increase risk, even at moderate altitudes.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Reduced exercise tolerance greater than expected at altitude.
    • Dry cough may precede, followed by blood-tinged sputum.
    • Tachypnea, tachycardia, crackles on auscultation.
    • Hypoxemia and respiratory alkalosis are present unless on acetazolamide (which may cause metabolic acidosis).
  • Investigation:
    • Chest X-ray: Patchy or streaky interstitial edema.
    • Electrocardiograms: Right ventricular strain or hypertrophy.
  • Prevention:
    • Gradual ascent is key to acclimatization.
    • Sustained-release nifedipine (30 mg twice daily) prevents HAPE in those ascending rapidly or with a history of HAPE.
    • Acetazolamide (Option D) and dexamethasone are potential options, though their roles require careful monitoring.
  • Treatment:
    • Immediate descent (Option C) and supplemental oxygen (Option B) (targeting >90% saturation) are the most effective treatments.
    • Maintain rest, warmth, and limit exertion.
    • Hyperbaric therapy (portable altitude chamber) may be lifesaving if descent is not possible.
    • Oral nifedipine as adjunctive therapy.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of a water bath for a patient with frostbite is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 37 degree C

Explanation: The recommended temperature of a water bath for a patient with frostbite is 37 degree C.

 

Frostbite:

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Tissue freezes below 0°C (32°F), leading to the ice-crystal formation that destroys the cellular structure.
    • Vascular endothelial damage causes stasis, microvascular thrombosis, and progressive dermal ischemia.
    • Thrombosis, ischemia, and necrosis lead to mummification and demarcation over weeks to months.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Sensory deficits (light touch, pain, or temperature perception); "chunk of wood" sensation in extremities.
    • Signs:
      • Superficial frostbite: Anesthesia, erythema, pliable subcutaneous tissue, and no tissue loss.
      • Deep frostbite: Waxy, mottled, violaceous-white tissue; hemorrhagic vesicles indicate severe injury.
  • Treatment:
    • Rewarming:
      • Immerse frozen tissue in circulating water at 37°- 40°C (99°-104°F) for 30-60 minutes.
      • Avoid premature termination of thawing despite the pain.
    • Medical Management:
      • Prostacyclin analogs (e.g., iloprost) within 48 hours.
      • Thrombolysis (rt-PA) and heparin for deep frostbite within 24 hours to reduce amputation risk.
    • Surgical Considerations: Delay debridement or amputation until demarcation.

questions.text: During a scorching summer afternoon, a man, who had been toiling in a field, unexpectedly collapsed. Upon examination, there were no apparent physical indications of dehydration, although his radial pulse was detectable. The doctor determined that the man's serum electrolyte levels were within the normal range. Shockingly, the man's body temperature measured 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Considering these circumstances, which of the following should be administered as an initial form of immediate assistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cover with cool damp sheets

Explanation:

  • The above patient seems to be suffering from a heat stroke. There are no signs of dehydration and the body temperature is quite high and the radial pulse is present. The next best step is to cover the body with cool damp sheets.

 

Epinephrine injection (Option A) can be fatal for the patient.

CPR (Option D) is not required as a steady radial pulse is perceived and the patient is not in shock.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of frostbite is incorrect?

choices.text: The area is dried and cleaned

questions.solution:
Antibiotics are commonly prescribed in the management of frostbite to prevent or treat secondary bacterial infections that can occur as a result of damaged tissue. Analgesics, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or opioids, may be used to manage pain.

 

In severe cases of frostbite where tissue damage is extensive and irreversible, amputation may be necessary to remove dead or gangrenous tissue (Option A) and prevent the spread of infection. Therefore, amputation can be a part of the management in severe cases.

 

Rewarming the affected area (Option B) is a critical step in the management of frostbite. It should be done using warm water (not hot) or by placing the affected area in a warm environment. Rewarming helps to restore blood flow and prevent further tissue damage.

 

After rewarming, the affected area should be gently dried and cleaned to prevent infection. (Option D) Cleaning helps remove any debris or contaminants from the damaged tissue.

questions.text:
A patient was being treated in ICU for sepsis.

The initial ABG shows pH= 6.9, pO2= 80 mm Hg. pCO2= 55 mmHg, HCO3 = 10 meq/L. A repeat ABG after 2 hours shows pH=7.1, pCO2= 20 mmHg, pO2= 140 mm Hg, and HCO3= 10 meq/L. Which is most plausible to explain the change seen in the ABG report?

choices.text: Excessive air and less heparin in the ABG sample
Excess air and more heparin in the ABG sample
Less air and more heparin in the ABG sample
Less air and less heparin in the ABG sample

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Excess air and more heparin in the ABG sample

Explanation:

  • The change in the pH without a change in the bicarbonate level indicates excess heparinization.
  • The increased pO2 shows excess air.

Effects of excess heparin:

  • Heparin is a sulfated mucopolysaccharide with acidic properties.
  • The excess of heparin in the ABG syringe can have the following effects:
  • Effect on pH:
    • If the pH is normal or alkaline (high) to begin with, acidemia increases i.e., the pH will fall on contact with the acidic heparin.
    • If the pH is very acidic to begin with, acidemia decreases i.e., the pH will rise as the mildly acidic heparin reduces the greater acidity of the blood.
  • Delusional effect:
    • The PaO2 and PaCO2 can also be falsely lowered by dilution.

questions.text: What medication can be administered to a patient who experiences altered consciousness, sweating, rapid heartbeat, persistent erection, and increased saliva production, with a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mm Hg after visiting a temple with their grandmother?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prazosin

Explanation:

  • The patient might be suffering from a scorpion sting cardiotoxicity as per his symptoms and the best choice of medication here is Prazosin.

Treatment of scorpion sting:

  • Identification of the scorpion species is essential for determining treatment, as stings from non-lethal species typically only require basic care.
  • Non-lethal stings: Most stings cause local discomfort and can be managed at home with ice packs, analgesics, or antihistamines. Patients should return to the emergency department if cranial-nerve or neuromuscular symptoms develop.
  • Severe envenomations: Aggressive supportive care and careful use of antivenom can prevent deaths from more dangerous stings.
  • Initial measures: Keeping the patient calm, applying pressure dressings, and using cold packs can reduce venom absorption.
  • Treatment for symptoms: Continuous IV infusion of midazolam can control agitation and muscle movements, but close monitoring is needed due to the risk of respiratory arrest, especially when sedatives or narcotics are used.
  • Management of complications:
    • Hypertension and Pulmonary oedema: Managed with Nifedipine, Nitroprusside, Hydralazine, or Prazosin.
    • Bradycardia: Managed with atropine.
  • Antivenin: FDA-approved antivenin (C. sculpturatus IgG F(ab')2 in horse serum) is available in some countries and can rapidly reverse cranial-nerve dysfunction and muscular symptoms when administered intravenously.

Incorrect Options:

Anti-snake venom (Option A) is a specific treatment used for snakebite envenomation and is not indicated in the given scenario.

Adrenaline (Option B) is commonly used in emergencies to treat severe allergic reactions and cardiac arrest.

Steroids (Option C), such as corticosteroids have anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. They are generally used in allergic reactions, autoimmune disorders, and asthma. However, these are not preferred in the given scenario.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the ER with anaphylaxis; which of the following not a part of the clinical criteria to diagnose anaphylaxis?


	Urticaria, edema of the lips and tongue, and rashes within 2 minutes to 2 hours of contact.
	Wheeze and respiratory distress
	Abdominal cramps and vomiting
	Hypertension
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3 and 4:

  • Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that typically occurs rapidly and involves multiple organ systems.
  • Although rare cases of hypertensive anaphylaxis exist, the typical cardiovascular manifestation of anaphylaxis is hypotension due to vasodilation and fluid shift from the intravascular space to the extravascular space.
  • Abdominal cramps and vomiting are not commonly associated with anaphylaxis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are clinically observed in case of anaphylaxis
  • Clinical criteria for the diagnosis of anaphylaxis, proposed at the Second National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease/Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Network (NIAID/FAAN) symposium, 2005.

Anaphylaxis is highly likely when any one of the following 3 criteria are fulfilled:

  • Acute onset of an illness (minutes to several hours) with involvement of the skin, mucosal tissue, or both (eg, generalized hives, pruritus or flushing, swollen lips-tongue-uvula) (And at Least One of The Following)
    • Respiratory compromise (eg, dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, reduced PEF, hypoxemia)
    • Reduced BP or associated symptoms of end-organ dysfunction (eg, hypotonia (collapse], syncope, incontinence)
  • Two or more of the following that occur rapidly after expo sun; to a likely allergen for that patient (minutes to several hours):
    • Involvement of the skin-mucosal tissue (eg, generalized hives, itch-flush, swollen lips-tongue-uvula)
    • Respiratory compromise (eg, dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, reduced PEF, hypoxemia)
    • Reduced BP or associated symptoms (eg, hypotonia [collapse], syncope, incontinence)
  • Reduced BP after exposure to known allergen for that patient (minutes to several hours):
    • Infants and children: low systolic BP (age specific) or greater than 30% decrease in systolic BP
    • Adults: systolic BP of less than 90 mm Hg or greater than 30% decrease from that person's baseline

questions.text: In a post-operative patient, after 2 hours of receiving FFP, sudden onset dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachypnea, hypotension, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray occur. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - TRALI (Transfusion-related acute lung injury):

  • TRALI is a severe adverse reaction that can occur within a few hours of FFP transfusion. It is characterized by the sudden onset of respiratory distress, pulmonary edema, and hypotension.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B - TACO (Transfusion-associated circulatory overload) - Presents with circulatory overload and pulmonary edema, but not tachypnea.

Option C - Pulmonary edema - General term for fluid accumulation in the lungs, but does not explain the specific findings mentioned.

Option D - ARDS (Acute respiratory distress syndrome) - Presents with severe respiratory distress, but the X-ray appearance is different (diffuse alveolar damage).

Option E - Sepsis - Infection-related, but does not explain the specific findings mentioned.

questions.text: What is the lifelong treatment for individuals who have received a potent prosthetic mitral valve replacement?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Warfarin:

  • All mechanical valves require long-term anticoagulation because they can cause systemic thromboembolism or may develop valve thrombosis or obstruction.
  • Warfarin helps prevent thrombogenic events by inhibiting the clotting proteins in the blood.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Aspirin acts on blood platelets only. Warfarin, instead, inhibits the circulating blood clotting proteins in the blood.

Option B - Clopidogrel also has anti-platelet action like aspirin. Both these drugs act on platelets and not on clotting proteins.

Option C - Atorvastatin is an anti-dyslipidemic drug. Patients with prosthetic valve requirements require regular intake of anticoagulants, more than anti-dyslipidemic.

questions.text: A farmer has come with symptoms of pinpoint pupils, excessive salivation, and increased secretion from the body. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Organophosphate poisoning:

  • Miosis pupil or pinpoint pupil, increased salivation, and body secretion are characteristic clinical features of organophosphorus poisoning.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - In opioid posing, the patient may present with pinpoint pupils. But they may not have features of increased salivation or body secretion.

Option C - In stroke, pinpoint pupils are present. But this essentially does not mean the patient had a stroke. Moreover, the patient may present with other neurological symptoms instead of increased body fluid secretion.

Option D - The patient suffers from extreme dehydration in heat stroke instead of increased salivation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with necrotizing fascitis was admitted to the ER. The patient was tachycardic and hypotensive. He was treated for septic shock. Which of the following is the characteristic feature of refractory septic shock?

choices.text: Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration
Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration and high dose vasopressors
Shock that is refractory to medical treatment
Shock that does not improve despite treatment for 24 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration and high-dose vasopressors:

  • Refractory septic shock is defined as septic shock that does not respond to initial fluid resuscitation and requires high doses of vasopressors to maintain mean arterial pressure.
  • The specific criteria often include persistence of shock despite adequate fluid resuscitation and high doses of vasopressors.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration: This option does not fully define refractory septic shock.

Option C - Shock that is refractory to medical treatment: This option is too broad and does not specifically address the criteria of IVF administration and high-dose vasopressors.

Option D - Shock that does not improve despite treatment for 24 hours: This option sets a specific time frame of 24 hours, which is not consistent with the definition of refractory septic shock.

questions.text: Which test is the most sensitive for diagnosing Organophosphate poisoning among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Plasma acetylcholinesterase: 

  • Organophosphate poisoning occurs inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine and excessive cholinergic activity.
  • The most sensitive test for the diagnosis of organophosphate poisoning is the measurement of plasma acetylcholinesterase levels. Reduced levels of plasma acetylcholinesterase activity indicate organophosphate poisoning.

Incorrect options:

Option B - (Organophosphate level in blood) is incorrect because the measurement of organophosphate levels in the blood is not the primary diagnostic test for organophosphate poisoning. The clinical effects and acetylcholinesterase activity are more indicative of the poisoning.

Option C - (Organophosphate level in plasma) is incorrect because the measurement of organophosphate levels in the plasma is not the primary diagnostic test for organophosphate poisoning. The clinical effects and acetylcholinesterase activity are more indicative of the poisoning.

Option D - (RBC transaminase levels) is incorrect because RBC transaminase levels are not relevant to the diagnosis of organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate was >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Check blood sugar level:

  • In the given scenario, the patient is elderly and presents in a comatose state with hypertension and tachycardia. The presence of bilateral extensor plantar reflex suggests significant neurological involvement.
  • Given the patient's history of diabetes and hypertension, it is important to first check the blood sugar level (Choice A) to evaluate for hypoglycemia.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Give antihypertensive: While the patient's blood pressure is elevated, administering antihypertensive medications (Choice B) without identifying the underlying cause can be potentially harmful.

Option  C - IV mannitol: IV mannitol (Choice C) is commonly used in the treatment of raised intracranial pressure or cerebral edema.

Option D - CT brain: A CT scan of the brain (Choice D) is an important diagnostic tool in the evaluation of a comatose patient with neurological findings.

questions.text: Which of the following is not done before drawing blood for arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Flexion of wrist:

  • It is important to keep the wrist in a neutral or slightly extended position during arterial puncture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allen's test: This test is performed to assess the collateral circulation in the hand before obtaining an arterial blood sample.

Option B - Rinse the syringe with heparin: Heparin is commonly used to prevent blood clotting in the syringe and maintain the integrity of the blood sample.

Option D - Placing needle at a 45-degree angle: When performing an arterial puncture, the needle is typically inserted at a 45-degree angle to the skin surface.
